I have always been intrigued by the concept of voting and how different voting systems try to implement concepts of 'fairness'. Moreover, the often used quote 'Not voting is like voting for your least favorite alternative' is confusing at times and incomprehensible at others. Hence, I decided to shed some light on these questions for my own sake and came across a (for me) surprising and important result: Arrow's theorem. Two very simple and commonly accepted properties of an electoral system are fundamentally irreconcilable if a dictatorial election is to be avoided. Let's dig in.

Any kind of voting system tries to introduce the concept of (partial) orderingfn-ordering by comparing different elements in a set (e.g. candidates in an election). Ordering in itself is a powerful concept, that together with the axiom of choice can be used to derive fundamental concepts of mathematics such as the natural numbers.

Since ordering is a mathematical concept it should be possible to derive general statments about voting and I stumbled over two well-known results: Arrow's and the Gibbard–Satterthwaite theoremsfn-theorem-reference. In their essence those results state that any voting system that tries to implement two rather favorable and important concepts from 'fair' election implies that the system resembles a dictatorship. To get a better understand this surprising result let's introduce some notation and concepts:

  • The set A={a,b}A=\{a,b\}A={a,b} of candidates is called alternatives. We use the notation a≻ba\succ ba≻b to indicate that candidate aaa is prefered over candidate bbb and the symbol ≻\succ≻ is said to induce a strict order on AAA.

A general expectation for any voting system is that if a candidate aaa is the favored choice of any voter then aaa is the winner of the election, i.e. is the winner of the social choice. In more mathematial terms this is called

  • Pareto Efficiency (PE): Whenever alternative aaa is at the top of every individual's iii ranking rir_iri​, then aaa is at the top of the social choice (election) ranking RRR

The term Pareto efficieny originates from game theory. It states that a system is Pareto efficient if there is no opportunity to increase the well-being of any individual without hurting the well-being of at least one other individual.

A second expectation for 'fair' elections is the desire for mutual independence of candidate comparisons: If an election has at least three alternatives a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c then the outcome should only depend on individual comparisons of aaa to bbb, aaa to ccc and bbb to ccc. In other words, the ranking of aaa to bbb should not depend on how the voters think about candidate ccc. To make this more rigorous we define the

  • Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives (IIA): If A={a,b}A = \{a, b\}A={a,b} and a≻ba\succ ba≻b then introducing a third alternative xxx cannot alter the preference profile of aaa and bbb.

The suprising result of Kenneth Arrow shows that any voting system that is Pareto Efficient and Independent of Irrelevant Alternatives has to be a dictatorship! A social welfare function is a

  • Dictatorship: If there is an individual iii whose preference sets candidate aaa on top, then the social choice (election) also put aaa on top, independent of the preferences of all other individuals.

We will not be deriving this result here, but there is a nice paper giving a very intuitive proof. Instead we will discuss some popular voting systems and their seemingly paradoxical outcomes. This will help to understand why the above statement might be true.

Popular Voting Systems and Examples

Let us look at some simple example to understand what the theorem implies and gain intuition about the complexity of election systems.

Example 1

We look at three groups of voters with their preference profiles after an election given by

499 voters: a≻b≻c498 voters: c≻b≻a3 voters: b≻c≻a\text{499 voters: } a \succ b \succ c \\ \text{498 voters: } c \succ b \succ a \\ \text{3 voters: } b \succ c \succ a499 voters: a≻b≻c498 voters: c≻b≻a3 voters: b≻c≻a

Depending on the voting schemes the outcome of the election is very different. Let us discuss some common systems:

  • Condorcet winner is the alternative who has the most votes when compared with any other alternative. In the above example the Condorcet winner is bbb: Comparing aaa to bbb we have 499:501499:501499:501, aaa to ccc results in 499:501499:501499:501 and bbb to ccc has 502:498502:498502:498 votes.
  • Borda count: We assign each position in the profile a number (weight) and sum the alternative's weights to create a final ranking. E.g. the top alternative has weight n−1n-1n−1, the second n−2n-2n−2 and so on, with the least favorite given a weight of 000. The Borda winner of the above voting profile is bbb.
  • Simple Plurality: The alternative with the most votes wins. In the above case aaa will be the winner.
  • Plurality with elimination (also called instant runoff or transferable voting): The alternative with the majority of votes is the winner. If there is no winner eliminate the alternative with the fewest votes and repeat until there is a winner. In the above case alternative ccc would be the winner: bbb has the fewest votes and hence will be eliminated, consequently we need to distribute the votes to candidates aaa and ccc after which ccc is the winner.

Example 2

Let us have a look at a different election with the outcomes:

35 voters: a≻c≻b33 voters: b≻a≻c32 voters: c≻b≻a\text{35 voters: } a \succ c \succ b \\ \text{33 voters: } b \succ a \succ c \\ \text{32 voters: } c \succ b \succ a35 voters: a≻c≻b33 voters: b≻a≻c32 voters: c≻b≻a

  • Successive Elimination: Before the election we decide on a pre-determined order in which candidates will be compared with each other and eliminated. This is very similar to a bracket system.

    • a, b, c ordering: Comparing aaa and bbb, bbb wins, which in turn looses to ccc. So the winner is ccc.
    • a, c, b ordering: The winner is bbb.
    • b, c, a ordering: The winner is aaa.

The other voting schemes produce aaa as the Condorcet, Borda and simple plurality winner and bbb as the plurality with elimination winner.

Some Shortcomings

Condorcet cycles

It seems that the Condorcet system is a very sensible choice for a voting system, however there are cases without such a winner. An example of this is rock-paper-scissor

1 voter: a≻b≻c1 voter: b≻c≻a1 voter: c≻a≻b\text{1 voter: } a \succ b \succ c \\ \text{1 voter: } b \succ c \succ a \\ \text{1 voter: } c \succ a \succ b1 voter: a≻b≻c1 voter: b≻c≻a1 voter: c≻a≻b

This example belongs to the more general class of Condorcet cycles paradox. Within rank ordering vote systems this problem can unfortunately not be solved and one has to resort to range voting systems. We will not go into further detail on those.

Successive Elimination

Let's look at the case where we introduce a fourth alternative ddd Before the election we agree on the elimination scheme a,b,c,da, b, c, da,b,c,d. The preference profile after the vote is:

1 voter: b≻d≻c≻a1 voter: a≻b≻d≻c1 voter: c≻a≻b≻d\text{1 voter: } b \succ d \succ c \succ a \\ \text{1 voter: } a \succ b \succ d \succ c \\ \text{1 voter: } c \succ a \succ b \succ d1 voter: b≻d≻c≻a1 voter: a≻b≻d≻c1 voter: c≻a≻b≻d

Who is the winner? Comparing aaa to bbb eliminates bbb. Next we compare aaa to ccc leaving ccc as a winner, who in turn losses to the final winner ddd.

Why is this a problem? If we only compared bbb to ddd then bbb is strictly Pareto-dominant over ddd. Nevertheless the successive elimination elects ddd as the winner.

Final words

All of the above voting schemes make significant trade-offs to avoid a dictatorial election system. Most often them give up the independence of irrelevant alternatives (IIA) and introduce dependencies on third party candidates, as they need tie-breakers. In the case of successive elimination, the pre-determined order ensures IIA for the election but then violates the Pareto efficiency (PE) as it allows a strictly dominated candidate to be elected as winner.

What these examples should teach us, is that whenever we have the option to vote, we should! Consequences of not voting are hard to understand and simple arguments are more wrong than right. If you consider not voting, make sure you understand the impacts. Especially in winner-takes-it-all electorial systems like the US, consequences can be large, as a few votes can change the outcome of an election by giving them inproportional leverage due to the number of electorial votes a state brings to the table.

  1. There are two sorts of orderings: Partial and Total (strict) ordering. The former relies on comparability between some elements in a set, whereas the later can induce a total order as all elements of the set are comparable and can thus be ordered.
